Joseph, can you run this through your tests and see if it meets your needs?
we lose these, do we care?
Nope.
I don't see this header anywhere, I think this can be removed. Oh well
Changed to X-Content-Type-Options
Can this comment be moved up to line 17? since all of these are from this
Moved.
So https://owasp.org/www-project-secure-headers/ci/headers_add.json says unoptimized-images=(self) here but might as well go more strict. Ack.
Made the edit on the fly.  WIll test shortly.
remove WIP since you tested?
Done
Do we care these went away ?
I don't think so.
@joseph?
No response from joseph in 10 days.  Lets just move forward.

(Sorry for the delay.  I wasn't getting email notifications.  I've updated my gerrit email setting.)

The results I see from various network security scan tools only care if a specific response header is present or not.  So if the goal is to placate the tool, adding a header is a big step forward.  For the header value, I think following OWASP by default is good, as modified by BMC-specific considerations.
I don't have any other insights into the scan tools.
Done

https://owasp.org/www-project-secure-headers/ci/headers_add.json has this as self. Are we following owasp? Or being more strict?

layout-animations=(self),legacy-image-formats=(self)

Lets follow them exactly for now, and if we can and should be more strict, lets do it in another patch.

Fixed my miss.

https://owasp.org/www-project-secure-headers/ci/headers_add.json has these as self. 

,sync-xhr=(self),unoptimized-images=(self),unsized-media=(self), 

I am wondering more the policy we are trying to follow
Fixed to follow owasp policy.
Matches https://owasp.org/www-project-secure-headers/ci/headers_add.json except  the "name": "Content-Security-Policy",
Seems okay to me.
Let me add those in the next patch so we can test separately.  CSP actually has the potential to break things, and I'd like to see the revert be simpler if need be.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/64426

Hi,
I guess webui-vue maintainers might want to re-evaluate this point, please see more inline.

webui-vue counts on Local Storage to preserve information about the user-selected UI language and whether to show all timestamps in UTC or local timezone. It looks like clearing that on logout is a regression UX-wise.
Also, clearing cache might introduce latency for certain pages and elements and it's not clear how it helps with security anyhow.

> webui-vue counts on Local Storage to preserve information about the user-selected UI language and whether to show all timestamps in UTC or local timezone. It looks like clearing that on logout is a regression UX-wise.

At the time I wrote that, I'm not sure I knew about the impact (I basically had never used webui-vue at that point).

I know Gunnar has had concerns about this as well for some IBM proxy, so the tradeoffs we have to consider are:
1. Do we care if we pass the OWASP test suite.
2. Do we want user-language to persist (in the browser)

We should look into best practices in OWASP, and get to the bottom of why the harness requires seeing this flag.  That'll probably lead to one of a couple outcomes:
1. We'll have to store the users timezone in redfish
2. We'll revert this patch, and leave persistent storage alone, and have documentation about why we don't pass venom
3. decide we don't care about venom, and just ignore it.

> Also, clearing cache might introduce latency for certain pages and elements and it's not clear how it helps with security anyhow.

This is us trying to pass the owasp test harness, so if you don't think it helps with security, I'd recommend following their process for changing their recommendations.  They're HTTP security experts, so I imagine they can validate whether or not this header helps with security.

The test atom for this is here:

https://github.com/oshp/oshp-validator/blob/0c6a88ee1948d8bed76ff70bf49fa371e52d601c/tests_suite.yml#L74

If a future version of the validator now passes without this header being present, then this is moot, and we can remove it.
